item.title: Ticket #920 (Calling wp_list_pages twice with different args does not work) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Acknowledged. Before these changes, it was broken in a different way: made one query per page, all the time. I plan to fix this by having a function much like get_page_uri, but that can take multiple page IDs at the same time; or have get_page_uri accept an array of page IDs.

item.title: Ticket #936 (Automatically Deleted Comments Still Appear in Database) created

item.title: Ticket #935 (client/admin code separation) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #935 (client/admin code separation) created
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
Right now, at every pageview we are loading functions that will never be used in that context: trackback(), do_enclose(), and so on. So we ought to separate those functions and put them in files that would only be required by the admin side of WP.

This bug serves as a tracker to audit the code and find which functions we need and don't need in the following contexts:

  • In the admin
  • On feeds
  • On pages with comments
  • On pages with posts

(list shamelessly copied from Matt's email on hackers@)

item.title: Ticket #901 (apply_filters's handling of extra arguments is broken) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: News patch, applies to the new SVN trunk. Fixes and optimises the code from the last patch: remove_filter was bugged, and apply_filter and do_action benefit from avoiding an array_slice if $accepted_args equals 1.

item.title: Ticket #901 (apply_filters's handling of extra arguments is broken) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
Uploaded a patch that adds support for both methods, this patch applies on CVS (so after the commit of the previous patch). This patch also fixes do_action so that it too can send extra arguments, and moves the :X parsing to add_filter and remove_filter in order to avoid doing this operation everytime apply_filter is called.

Internally, filters are stored as [tag][priority][array(function, accepted_args)]. It could have been more optimal to store them as [tag][priority][function][accepted_args], since this would allow for simple issets to check for a filter's presence, but this would be incompatible with the usage of class methods (since those are passed as arrays, and we can't use arrays as array keys). To use them as array keys, we could also use serialize/unserialize, but that would add to the operations done when doing apply_filter, so it would be rather bad.

instead of echo $title;

will fix this problem

item.title: Ticket #924 (RSS2 feed does not validate when using translation mo file) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Try the following patch:

diff -r1.37 wp-rss2.php 36c36 < <pubDate><?php echo mysql2date('D, d M Y H:i:s +0000', get_the_time('Y-m-d H:i:s')); ?></pubDate> ---

<pubDate><?php echo mysql2date('D, d M Y H:i:s +0000', get_the_time('Y-m-d H:i:s'), 0); ?></pubDate>

Everywhere you see a call to mysql2date in a feed file, make sure the call has a third argument of 0.

item.dc:creator: pvera
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #926 (Wrong redirect after add/edit/delete custom fields) created
item.dc:creator: pvera
item.description: Whenever I add/edit or delete a custom field, I am sent to a 404, the URL shows /wp-admin/&message=2#postcustom or /wp-admin/&message=3#postcustom

item.title: Ticket #925 (install.php does not set the Content-Type header) updated
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #925 (install.php does not set the Content-Type header) created
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description:
No Content-Type header is sent by WordPress. Instead it seems to be relying on using the <meta http-equiv="Content-Type"> tag only.

This can result in the wrong character set to be used. regardless of the <meta http-equiv="Content-Type"> tag on the page. The character set in the response headers seems to take precedence (Firefox 1.0).

The headers on a fresh install on my server:

Date: Sat, 19 Feb 2005 23:41:19 GMT Server: Apache Cache-Control: max-age=3600 Expires: Sun, 20 Feb 2005 00:41:19 GMT Keep-Alive: timeout=15, max=98 Connection: Keep-Alive Transfer-Encoding: chunked Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1

The Finnish translation of the "Already installed" error has UTF-8 characters, and they get displayed incorrectly.

item.title: Ticket #924 (RSS2 feed does not validate when using translation mo file) updated
item.dc:creator: Stedi
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #924 (RSS2 feed does not validate when using translation mo file) created
item.dc:creator: Stedi
item.description:
If you translate the weekdays Sun,Mon,Tue,Wed,Thu,Fri,Sat between lines 717-743 in the wordpress.pot file, the RSS2 feed does not validate anymore.

"pubDate must be an RFC-822 date"

So "complete" translation breaks the feed validation.

item.title: Ticket #901 (apply_filters's handling of extra arguments is broken) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Uploaded a fix to the forementioned patch. (Hat tip: Ryan)

item.title: Ticket #901 (apply_filters's handling of extra arguments is broken) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Uploaded a patch that adds :num_args support and fixes the "whoops we don't send args" issue. The is_array check is done so we can support multiple args for methods in classes. Array('class', 'method:5') is how you tell WP that the method 'method' in class 'class' supports 5 arguments.

item.title: Ticket #920 (Calling wp_list_pages twice with different args does not work) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #920 (Calling wp_list_pages twice with different args does not work) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
The get_pages() function caches the page list and returns it in later calls.

For example 1: get_pages("child_of=3"); 2: get_pages("child_of=24");

In this case the second call returns the same result as the first one.

item.title: Ticket #919 (Need way of escaping wpautop for blocks of text) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #919 (Need way of escaping wpautop for blocks of text) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
It would be really nice is there was a way to designate blocks of text to be untouched by wpautop, maybe by special html comment designators.

People are trying to add e-mail addresses to their contact page using the EnKoder thing, and wpautop just eats the code up.

They have to turn wpautop off, like this:

add_action('wp_head', create_function('$a', 'if(is_page("contact")) remove_filter("the_content", "wpautop");'));

But then you lose all of wpautop's benefits.

item.title: Ticket #918 (Unformatted excerpts) updated
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #918 (Unformatted excerpts) created
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description:
When using Markdown, the_excerpt can output raw Markdown code. This happens when the excerpt is created from the content, by truncating it. Markdown can include references further into the document, so the complete document has to be processed before truncating.

For example, if you follow the examples on Daring Fireball, you'll place all your link references at the bottom of the document. Since they will be truncated away, the unresolved Markdown code remains in the output.

item.title: Ticket #908 (Categories Will Not Sort by Name) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: I would classify this as major -- hierarchical is also being ignored, which means that all categories, parent and child, are being flattened into one level and then sorted by id, thus sprinkling children in between different primary categories. my child categories are named such that much of their meaning is derived from their parent. absent the parent-child relationship, my category names become fairly meaningless and certainly confusing.
